Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial
Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial
Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

evidence.text: The State of Mississippi has severely underfunded its prison system for years. This is a virtually undisputed fact.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Mississippi state has severely underfunded its prison system for years.

evidence.text: The lack of funding has resulted in shortages of basic inmate necessities (i.e. clean water, functional plumbing and electricity, etc.) and prison staff to oversee and maintain control over the Parchman facility.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Lack of funding has resulted in shortages of basic inmate necessities such as clean water, functional plumbing, and electricity.

evidence.text: In January 2019, Defendant Hall acknowledged that the near‑capacity prison populations and extreme staff vacancy rates had created a "staffing crisis," which threatened a "pressure cooker type situation" in the MDOC's three state‑run prisons, including Parchman.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: In January 2019, Defendant Hall acknowledged that near‑capacity prison populations and extreme staff vacancy rates created a staffing crisis.

evidence.text: At the time of her statement, Parchman had a 42% staff vacancy rate.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: At the time of the statement, Parchman had a 42% staff vacancy rate.

evidence.text: Parchman has a maximum capacity of 3,560 prisoners and a current population of 3,252 prisoners.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Parchman has a maximum capacity of 3,560 prisoners and a current population of 3,252 prisoners.

evidence.text: The United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division issued a report in which it cited the Alabama Department of Corrections ("ADOC") for "egregious" and "dangerous" systemwide understaffing that contributed to likely violations of the Eighth Amendment rights of Alabama prisoners.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: The United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division issued a report citing the Alabama Department of Corrections for egregious understaffing that contributed to likely violations of the Eighth Amendment.

evidence.text: ADOC maintains a staffing ratio of 9.9 prisoners per correctional officer.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: The DOJ report states that the Alabama Department of Corrections maintains a staffing ratio of 9.9 prisoners per correctional officer.

evidence.text: At the end of October 2019, the staffing ratio at Parchman (12.5 prisoners per correctional officer) was worse than Alabama's.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: At the end of October 2019, the staffing ratio at Parchman was 12.5 prisoners per correctional officer, worse than Alabama's.

evidence.text: Mississippi currently pays the lowest salaries for correctional staff of any state in the country. The MDOC offers entry level correctional officers a salary of $24,900.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Mississippi currently pays the lowest salaries for correctional staff of any state, with entry‑level officers earning $24,900.

evidence.text: The State of Mississippi spends $3,770 per inmate, which is less than the national median expenditure per inmate.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: The State of Mississippi spends $3,770 per inmate, less than national median.

evidence.text: Parchman prison units have been flooded and are now covered in black mold.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Parchman prison units have been flooded and are covered in black mold.

evidence.text: Toilets back up, resulting in floors covered with raw sewage.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Toilets back up, resulting in floors covered with raw sewage.

evidence.text: Electricity and running water are provided only sporadically.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Electricity and running water are provided only sporadically.

evidence.text: The prison has been cited for violating the Safe Drinking Water Act nearly 100 times since 2012.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: The prison has been cited for violating the Safe Drinking Water Act nearly 100 times since 2012.

evidence.text: The Environmental Protection Agency has cited the prison's sewage system for three years for violating the Clean Water Act.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: The EPA has cited the prison's sewage system for three years for violating the Clean Water Act.

evidence.text: A 2019 Mississippi Department of Health inspection of Parchman found "more than 400 cells with problems such as flooding and leaks, lack of lights, power and water, broken toilets and sinks as well as missing pillows and mattresses."
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: A 2019 Mississippi Department of Health inspection found over 400 cells with flooding, leaks, lack of lights, power, water, broken toilets and sinks.

evidence.text: Mississippi has reduced its expenditure on the MDOC by $185 million since 2014.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Mississippi has reduced expenditure on the MDOC by $185 million since 2014.

evidence.text: During the closing days of December 2019, the "pressure cooker" situation of which Defendant Hall spoke reached a breaking point at Parchman.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: The "pressure cooker" situation reached a breaking point at Parchman in December 2019.

evidence.text: Since January 1, 2020, at least nine inmates have died at Parchman, and at least two other inmates have escaped.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Since January 1, 2020, at least nine inmates have died at Parchman, and at least two other inmates have escaped.

evidence.text: The understaffing at Parchman presents an imminent risk to Plaintiffs.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Understaffing at Parchman presents an imminent risk to plaintiffs.

evidence.text: This is a class action complaint filed for money damages on behalf of prisoners confined at the Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman (“Parchman”) against Defendants PELICIA E. HALL, TOMMY TAYLOR, MARSHAL TURNER, JEWORSKI MALLETT, BRENDA S. COX, TIMOTHY MORRIS, LEE SIMON, MARYLEN STURDIVANT, WENDELL BANKS, VERLENA FLAGG, JEWEL MORRIS, LEATHER WILLIAMS, EARNEST KING, LAQUITTA MEEKS, STANLEY FLAGG, CLAUDE LEE, PEGGY LATHAN, OLIVIA WESTMORELAND, CAREN WEBB, TERRY HAYWOOD, AUDREY FIELDS, and JOHN AND JANE DOES (1-500), who allege as follows: This is a class action complaint filed for money damages on behalf of prisoners confined at the Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman (“Parchman”) against Defendants PELICIA E. HALL, TOMMY TAYLOR, MARSHAL TURNER, JEWORSKI MALLETT, BRENDA S. COX, TIMOTHY MORRIS, LEE SIMON, MARYLEN STURDIVANT, WENDELL BANKS, VERLENA FLAGG, JEWEL MORRIS, LEATHER WILLIAMS, EARNEST KING, LAQUITTA MEEKS, STANLEY FLAGG, CLAUDE LEE, PEGGY LATHAN, OLIVIA WESTMORELAND, CAREN WEBB, TERRY HAYWOOD, AUDREY FIELDS, and JOHN AND JANE DOES (1-500), who allege as follows:
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: This is a class action complaint filed for money damages on behalf of prisoners confined at the Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman (“Parchman”) against Defendants PELICIA E. HALL, TOMMY TAYLOR, MARSHAL TURNER, JEWORSKI MALLETT, BRENDA S. COX, TIMOTHY MORRIS, LEE SIMON, MARYLEN STURDIVANT, WENDELL BANKS, VERLENA FLAGG, JEWEL MORRIS, LEATHER WILLIAMS, EARNEST KING, LAQUITTA MEEKS, STANLEY FLAGG, CLAUDE LEE, PEGGY LATHAN, OLIVIA WESTMORELAND, CAREN WEBB, TERRY HAYWOOD, AUDREY FIELDS, and JOHN AND JANE DOES (1-500), who allege as follows: This is a class action complaint filed for money damages on behalf of prisoners confined at the Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman (“Parchman”) against Defendants PELICIA E. HALL, TOMMY TAYLOR, MARSHAL TURNER, JEWORSKI MALLETT, BRENDA S. COX, TIMOTHY MORRIS, LEE SIMON, MARYLEN STURDIVANT, WENDELL BANKS, VERLENA FLAGG, JEWEL MORRIS, LEATHER WILLIAMS, EARNEST KING, LAQUITTA MEEKS, STANLEY FLAGG, CLAUDE LEE, PEGGY LATHAN, OLIVIA WESTMORELAND, CAREN WEBB, TERRY HAYWOOD, AUDREY FIELDS, and JOHN AND JANE DOES (1-500), who allege as follows:

evidence.text: videos have surfaced showing that inmates are being required to defecate in plastic bags inside of their cells because their toilets are not functional.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The court finds that the defendants failed to provide adequate staffing and resources at the Mississippi State Penitentiary, resulting in inmates being forced to defecate in plastic bags inside cells due to non-functional toilets.

evidence.text: The underfunding and lack of Defendant’s adherence to policies and/or customs that would have alleviated the complaints made herein, also forces people held in Mississippi’s prison to live in squalor, endangering their physical and mental health.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: Underfunding and lack of defendant adherence to policies and customs have forced people held in Mississippi’s prison to live in squalor, endangering their physical and mental health.

evidence.text: In Parchman, the units are subject to flooding. Black mold festers. Rats and mice infest the prison. Units lack running water and electricity for days at a time.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The prison units are subject to flooding, black mold, rats and mice infestations, and lack running water and electricity for days.

evidence.text: Since January 1, 2020, at least nine inmates have died at Parchman, and at least two other inmates have escaped from Parchman.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: Severe understaffing and neglect have caused multiple inmate deaths and escapes at Parchman.

evidence.text: The State of Mississippi has severely underfunded its prison system for years. This is a virtually undisputed fact. The occurrences alleged and facts stated herein are a symptom of Mississippi’s well‑documented failures to adequately fund, staff, and maintain its prisons.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The state of Mississippi has severely underfunded its prison system for years, leading to a shortage of basic inmate necessities.

evidence.text: The lack of funding has resulted in shortages of basic inmate necessities (i.e., clean water, functional plumbing and electricity, etc.) and prison staff to oversee and maintain control over the Parchman facility.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The lack of funding has resulted in shortages of clean water, functional plumbing, and electricity at Parchman.

evidence.text: Parchman has a maximum capacity of 3,560 prisoners and a current population of 3,252 prisoners.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: Parchman’s maximum capacity is 3,560 prisoners, but its current population is 3,252.

evidence.text: In April 2019, the United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division issued a report in which it cited the Alabama Department of Corrections ("ADOC") for "egregious" and "dangerous" systemwide understaffing that contributed to likely violations of the Eighth Amendment rights of Alabama prisoners.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The Department of Justice’s Civil Rights Division issued a report citing the Alabama Department of Corrections for egregious and dangerous understaffing.

evidence.text: Defendants here engaging in behavior that violates prisoner’s civil rights.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: Defendants’ actions and non‑actions violate prisoners’ civil rights.

evidence.text: The Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman, a maximum‑security prison built on the site of a former plantation, has only one‑quarter of the corrections officers it needs and many that are absent.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman is a maximum‑security prison built on the site of a former plantation.

evidence.text: The prisons have failed to provide the basic necessities, such as a place to sleep.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The prison has failed to provide basic necessities such as a place to sleep.

evidence.text: Nearly half of the prison guard slots for Mississippi’s prisons remain unfilled.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The state has reduced funding for prisons, resulting in unfilled guard slots.

evidence.text: The shortage of correctional officers on staff at Parchman, and the actions and non‑actions of individual Defendants’ regarding the allegations herein, creates an environment in which the inmates at Parchman are particularly susceptible to violence, gang influence, and prolonged states of anarchy.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The prison environment creates a heightened risk of violence, gang influence, and anarchy.

evidence.text: Parchman has been in an ongoing state of crisis. The inexcusable chaos which has ensued within the prison has been due in large part to the glaring insufficiency of correctional officers and the actions and non‑actions of individual Defendants’ regarding the allegations herein.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The prison has been in an ongoing state of crisis due to insufficient staffing.

evidence.text: The State of Mississippi has severely underfunded its prison system for years. This is a virtually undisputed fact. The occurrences alleged and facts stated herein are a symptom of Mississippi’s well‑documented failures to adequately fund, staff, and maintain its prisons.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The state’s failure to fund, staff, and maintain prisons has caused widespread neglect.

evidence.text: The lack of funding has resulted in shortages of basic inmate necessities (i.e., clean water, functional plumbing and electricity, etc.) and prison staff to oversee and maintain control over the Parchman facility.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The lack of funding has led to shortages of basic inmate necessities and prison staff.

evidence.text: The shortage of correctional officers on staff at Parchman, and the actions and non‑actions of individual Defendants’ regarding the allegations herein, creates an environment in which the inmates at Parchman are particularly susceptible to violence, gang influence, and prolonged states of anarchy.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: Defendants’ failure to act or act negligently has contributed to the crisis.

evidence.text: See Amanda Watts, Ninth Inmate Dies at Mississippi’s Parchman Prison Since the Start of the Year, CNN (Jan. 27, 2020); See Two Prisoners Escape Mississippi Prison After Weeks of Violence, WMC NEWS (Jan. 4, 2020); See China Lee, One Inmate Killed, Others Injured During Riot at Parchman, WLOX (Jan. 2, 2020); See Bryan Davis Publisher, One Confirmed Dead in Second Parchman Riot in as Many Days, ENTERPRISE‑TOCSIN (Jan. 2, 2020).
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: The prison’s conditions have been documented in multiple media reports and investigative pieces.

args.reason: All checklist items have been extracted and are complete.
All checklist items have been extracted and are complete.
